Description: Head of a bearded male figure with almond shaped eyes, possibly a komast. Mould-made and hollow. Possible traces of paint around eyes. Fine, beige, loamy clay with very small mica; traces of colour. Broken at neck, probably the neck of a figure-shaped scent bottle, the rim is broken and lost. Only the front half preserved.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels from Kamiros, Rhodes of scent bottles in the form of kneeling or seated men (Higgins 1970, nos 79, 82, 83; British Museim GR 1865,1214.34, 1860,0404.56, 1931,1014.1; Jacopi 1933, 292-8) dated c.530BC and late 6th century BC. The fabric, parallels and style are consistent with a Rhodian provenance, though another Ionian origin cannot be excluded. For discussion of komast subject see Dasen (2010) and Mandel (2004, 48-9). Dasen, V. 2010, ‘Squatting comasts and sacarb-beetles’, in G.R. Tsteskhladze, A.J.N.W. Prag and A.M. Snodgrass (eds), Periplous: Papers on Classical Art and Archaeology Presented to Sir John Boardman, Oxford, 89–97. Jacopi, G. 1933. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro II. Clara Rhodos 6-7. Mandel, U. 2004, ‘Ägyptische Schemata in ostgriechischer Aneignung: Figürliche salbgefässe und terrakotten des 6. Jahrhunderts V. Chr’, in H. Beck, P.C. Bol, G. Kaminski and C. Maderna (eds), Fremdheit – Eigenheit Ägypten, Griechenland und Rom Austausch und Verständnis, Städel Jahrbuch Neue Folge 19, Stuttgart, 47–71.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.040) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5927 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
